newsitem.title: USA: Hatches close between U.S. shuttle and Mir.
newsitem.headline: Hatches close between U.S. shuttle and Mir.

text.p: The hatches between the U.S. space shuttle Atlantis and Russia's space station Mir swung shut on Wednesday as the two space crews prepared to go their separate ways.

The tunnel connecting the two spacecraft was closed at 8:43 a.m. EDT (1243 GMT), five days after Atlantis arrived at Mir to collect Jerry Linenger, who spent 122 days aboard the station, and drop off his replacement Michael Foale.
The shuttle crew said their farewells to Foale and his Russian crewmates, Vasily Tsibliev and Alexander Lazutkin, and one by one floated back aboard Atlantis.
"We'll see you," shuttle skipper Charles Precourt told the waving Mir crew before the first hatch swung shut.
"We've wished them well," Precourt radioed mission control. "Just kind of sorry to see them close the hatch."
The hatches closed about an hour later than planned to accommodate an astronaut's last-minute consultation with a mission control doctor and to allow some final cargo exchanges.
Atlantis was due to uncouple from Mir at 9:04 p.m. EDT (0104 GMT Thursday) and return to Earth on Saturday.
Before the hatches closed, Linenger gave mission control a televised tour of Mir and recalled the events of Feb. 23 when a serious fire broke out.
Fighting the fire was difficult because of the cramped conditions aboard the station and visibility was near zero, he explained.
"You could sort of see your fingers if you looked hard," he said. "It was very, very dense smoke. An interesting experience, something you don't want to repeat, of course."
The blaze also blocked the route to one of the Soyuz spacecraft which would have been needed to evacuate the station.
"It would have been very difficult to get through the flame itself to get to one of the rescue vehicles," he said. At the time of the blaze there were six crew members aboard the station.
During the tour, Linenger pointed out the space station's emergency breathing masks. They "saved our lives" he said.
The fire was the first in a string of mechanical breakdowns that marred Linenger's stay aboard Mir. Problems with the life support systems and leaks in the cooling systems followed.
NASA approved Foale's stay on Mir after most of the malfunctions were corrected. The British-born astronaut said he had no qualms living aboard the troubled, 11-year-old space station.

"As far as my worries, I don't really have any right now," Foale told a news conference on Wednesday. "As long as we keep working hard with the ground and keep the supplies coming, we can maintain these things."
As for Linenger, he only had one concrete plan after returning to Earth: "I'm going fishing," he said.
